title: Judgment on Mount Seir
shortSummary: Ezekiel 35 records God's pronouncement of judgment against Mount Seir, representing Edom, for its longstanding hatred and violence against Israel. The chapter emphasizes God's sovereignty and justice, declaring desolation upon Edom and affirming that His name will be known through this judgment.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the Babylonian exile, when Ezekiel prophesied against Israel's neighbors

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet receiving and delivering God's word, tasked here with prophesying against Mount Seir.

keyCharacters.name: Mount Seir (Edom)
keyCharacters.description: The geographical and symbolic representation of Edom, a nation hostile to Israel, subject of God's judgment in this chapter.

definitions.definition: A mountainous region inhabited by the Edomites, descendants of Esau, often hostile to Israel.
To be laid waste or made uninhabitable, often as a result of divine judgment.
An ongoing, unrelenting hostility or enmity, especially referring to Edom's hatred toward Israel.
Irreverent or insulting speech against God or His people.

outline.heading: Divine Command to Prophesy Against Mount Seir
outline.description: God instructs Ezekiel to confront Mount Seir with a prophecy of judgment, declaring His opposition and intent to make it desolate.

outline.heading: Reason for Judgment: Edom’s Hatred and Violence
outline.description: God explains that Edom's continual hatred and bloodshed against Israel during their calamity has provoked His wrath.

outline.heading: The Extent of Desolation Foretold
outline.description: God declares that Mount Seir will be made most desolate, with cities laid waste and many slain, so that all will know He is the LORD.

outline.heading: Edom’s Boast and God’s Response
outline.description: Edom arrogantly claimed Israel’s lands as their own, but God promises to judge them for their envy and blasphemy.

outline.heading: Final Pronouncement of Judgment and Revelation of God’s Sovereignty
outline.description: God promises to make Edom desolate as they rejoiced over Israel’s ruin, revealing His justice and making His name known.

application: Recognize that God sees and judges persistent hatred and violence, encouraging believers to pursue peace and forgiveness.
Trust in God's sovereign justice, knowing that He will defend His people and punish their enemies in His perfect timing.
Avoid boasting or envy over others’ misfortunes, as God calls His people to humility and reliance on His righteousness.
Remember that God's name is made known through both mercy and judgment, motivating us to live in reverence and obedience.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the Lord GOD; Behold, O mount Seir, I am against thee, and I will stretch out mine hand against thee, and I will make thee most desolate.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly states God's direct judgment against Edom, emphasizing His sovereign authority to bring desolation.

keyVerses.text: Therefore, as I live, saith the Lord GOD, I will prepare thee unto blood, and blood shall pursue thee: sith thou hast not hated blood, even blood shall pursue thee.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the principle of divine retribution, showing that Edom’s violence will be repaid in kind.

keyVerses.text: I will make thee perpetual desolations, and thy cities shall not return: and ye shall know that I am the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the permanence of God's judgment and the ultimate recognition of His lordship.

keyVerses.text: As thou didst rejoice at the inheritance of the house of Israel, because it was desolate, so will I do unto thee: thou shalt be desolate, O mount Seir, and all Idumea, even all of it: and they shall know that I am the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: God promises a just recompense for Edom’s rejoicing over Israel’s downfall, affirming His justice and sovereignty.
